Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's trademark 'Home Sentinel & Design' is confusingly similar to the plaintiff's trademarks
Evidence_Assessment: Witness testimonies, market differences, appearance and usage context of marks
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to prove likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly mentioned, but evidence credibility assessed through market and consumer targeting differences
Legal_Rule: Confusion is determined by the likelihood that the public would infer both marks are associated with the same entity
Standard_of_Review: Likelihood of confusion under s. 6(5) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Issue: Analysis focused on confusion using statutory factors
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged trademark infringement and request for expungement
Outcome_on_Merits: No infringement found; defendant's mark allowed to coexist
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Not applicable â€“ no appeal indicated
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and application of s. 6(5) factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Common use of 'sentinel', target consumer groups, product vs. service context, visual and conceptual differences in marks
Applicant_Challenge: Plaintiff challenged validity and use of defendant's mark
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 20 and Section 6(5) of the Trade-marks Act
Defendant_Response: Denial of confusion; distinction in branding, audience, and services
Authority: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian trademark law
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Trademark infringement based on alleged confusion
Applicable_Process: Civil litigation process under federal trademark law
Governing_Rule: Factors in s. 6(5) of the Trade-marks Act for determining confusion
